title: What splash arts tell the best stories?
body:
A lot of skin lines have whole backstories to them, but the only things we know about them come from voice lines and the splash art. For example, the Arclight skin line was originally just Varus mixed with Kid Icarus, but then a story was created out of that skin. Now the story is that Varus and Vayne are 
"holy avengers uplifted by a gigantic golden-tentacled god (so in his splash Vel'koz is testing the faithful and Varus and Vayne are supernatural zealots that passed that test and ascended)."
 - RIOT Kindlejack

So I think that splash arts are meant to give you that first look into a skin or champion, and it really is a great splash art that tells a tale. For example:
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/C4QHRGvVcAADjYq.jpg
This is a great splash art. Most people agree with me on that. But I feel that it's so much more than just a picture of Diana as a demon priestess. I see a person who has made a pact with a demon mask, one that gives her the power to accompish her righteous goals, but a demon nonetheless. The sigil that seems burned on to her forehead is proof of this contract, but the expression on her face seems subdued, like she knows she has to put on the mask, but also knows that she loses herself in the process.
When I thought up my question, this was really the only splash that immediately came to mind, but feel free to discuss more than one splash.

So that's that. Now, what splash art (including base splashes) do you find that *you* can overanalyze? What splashes do *you* think tell a deeper story?

Undertake Yorick, Easy. It perfectly depicts his theme of rebellion, with going against the Shadow Isles, but it also has an eerie storybook feel. His model and the background perfectly depict his character. Looking at the background, you see how grim the world is. The fact he's emerging out of it speaks wonders for who he is. And all this, Just for a skin. That's not even his default!

I don't remember the exact timing of when they came out, but the skins in this splash have some of the same design aspects as Undertaker Yorick. They could also be related in terms of skin lore.

Same design, but nothing more, Granted, I LOVE the art style on those, but Yorick's here has ulterior meanings. Those are nothing more then images on a story book. 

The only ulterior motive of that picture is that behind each character depicts and element of who they are. Note Kayle has wings, in the background. Singed is giving off Gas at the lower-left, and ...Well. I don't see anything for Noc. Either way though, Yorick's tells a story. Those just look really nice.

It was a really interesting way to push group splash art at the time, then with the Yorick update Undertaker was redesigned to fit into the same world. I hope we can do more in the future... I really want to know who holds this book and hunts these monsters.

I quite liked the Kayle/Noc/Singed group splash, it really shows that group splash arts CAN be good and even become amongst the best Splashes in the game. 

Why is that we get really good one like these, but then get the horrible ones like the Monster Hunter and the Bard Bard/Dawnchaser Sej splashes?

Is it just bad compositioning from the Artist's side? Or is it a choice by the overall team? 
There were MUCH better ways to compose and position those Artworks, so I don't know why we got such terrible results.

A lot of it is experimentation. Group splashes are a way to resolve bandwidth issues (if you know any illustrators that can hit our splash quality please send them our way, I think we've hired them all) and the splash discipline have tried tackling the challenge in different ways:

Beast Hunter tried a dynamic composition that focused on the fantasy more than the individual skins, while Gothic Horror used a creative break with tradition to focus on the skins. Similarly the Chef group splash tried to create a composition that put equal focus on all the characters and have them interacting, while the RPG (part 2) splash was a large 'master' piece that had each individual's splash cropped and blurred from.

Something we talk about a lot is balancing product goals with artistic principles. The Beast Hunter splash actually has fantastic composition - for a painting, but doesn't work as well for showcasing the skins. The Gothic Horror splash focuses heavily on the purpose of a splash but at the cost of a more singular work of art.

Also try to remember when it comes to opinions on the art there are players who love a splash and players who don't, not everyone feels the same way! Your final paragraph could dissuade people from respecting your comments.

I appreciate the reply as usual. 

I'll start by saying that I will NEVER censor myself in that way. 
Everyone knows my comments are my own opinion as they are my comment.  
Whether someone respects my opinion or not, is their own prerogative. 
People don't go into things with an empty mind, they will have decided on whether they respect my opinion regardless of how I word it. 
You do you and I'll do me, is what I always say. 

I'll have to agree that yes, the Splash work well as Art pieces, but they don't an absolute atrocious job as splash-arts.
I can 100% understand why Riot might want to try the whole Artsy dynamic style, but I think more thought needs to be put into them when you really decide to do them. 

You don't only do a terrible job of showcasing the skins,
but do a **great job** of alienating players who might want to see their champion represented well.

I don't think it should be such a binary choice.
I would think that you at least TRY to represent ALL of the champions in the splash-art before doing anything else, but it's unfortunately not the case. 
In the end they are SPLASH ARTS, and I can't see the argument where that takes a back seat to representing the white generic male characters in the foreground all the time (Not being political, just pointing out a trend).

Sejuani was messed over twice, Tryndamere was in the monster hunter and Bard in the RPG splash, and the same thing is done again and again in 90% of group splashes.
If you could explain the process a little bit more that'd be appreciated, because it really makes no sense why these kind of things happen. 

It really doesn't help or make anyone feel better when blatant bias comes into it either, or that Riot feels the need to cling to generics. It's a massive bummer when you see stuff like this happen, especially when it all could have been avoided so easily.
